Privacy-preserving Decentralized Federated Learning over Time-varying Communication Graph

Yang Lu Lancaster UniversityInfoLab21LancasterUK y.lu44@lancaster.ac.uk ,  Zhengxin Yu Lancaster UniversityInfoLab21LancasterUK z.yu8@lancaster.ac.uk  and  Neeraj Suri Lancaster UniversityInfoLab21LancasterUK neeraj.suri@lancaster.ac.uk
(2022)
Abstract.

Establishing how a set of learners can provide privacy-preserving federated learning in a fully decentralized (peer-to-peer, no coordinator) manner is an open problem. We propose the first privacy-preserving consensus-based algorithm for the distributed learners to achieve decentralized global model aggregation in an environment of high mobility, where the communication graph between the learners may vary between successive rounds of model aggregation. In particular, in each round of global model aggregation, the Metropolis-Hastings method (Xiao et al., 2007) is applied to update the weighted adjacency matrix based on the current communication topology. In addition, the Shamir’s secret sharing scheme (Shamir, 1979) is integrated to facilitate privacy in reaching consensus of the global model. The paper establishes the correctness and privacy properties of the proposed algorithm. The computational efficiency is evaluated by a simulation built on a federated learning framework with a real-word dataset.

federated learning, decentralized aggregation, privacy, mobility

1. Introduction

1.1. Background and Motivation

Federated learning is a collaborative machine learning technique providing privacy preservation of the individual learners’ local training data (McMahan et al., 2017a; Konečný et al., 2016). Each learner downloads the current global model from a centralized server, updates it by incorporating its local training data, and then sends the updated model back to the server. The server then aggregates the local models of all the individual learners to update the global model. Thus, only local training models can be observed during the training process, while raw training data do not leave their owners’ devices. Given this significant feature of privacy preservation, federated learning has been applied to a wide range of applications, including wireless communications (Niknam et al., 2019), autonomous driving (Elbir et al., 2020), multi-access edge computing (Yu et al., 2021), smart manufacturing (Cioffi et al., 2020), and healthcare (Xu et al., 2021).

The traditional federated learning paradigm has two major issues. First, it requires a centralized server such that it is connected to all the local learners. In some scenarios, the learners are geographically dispersed over a large area and may lack such a connect-to-all server. In addition, the paradigm is not robust, since if the single centralized server fails, then the whole learning task cannot proceed. Second, the local training models are directly uploaded to the centralized server. As has been recently pointed out (Fredrikson et al., 2015; Nasr et al., 2019), it is possible that private local training data can be reconstructed from local training models via model inference or inversion attacks. The above two issues necessitate new mechanisms that can achieve federated learning in a decentralized and privacy-preserving manner.

1.2. Related Works

Multiple recent works have addressed the issue with fixed centralized server. Based on the technologies in achieving model aggregation, these works can be mainly categorized into two classes. The first class of works dynamically selects a learner to take the role of the centralized server (Roy et al., 2019; Che et al., 2021; Yu et al., 2020). Informally, for each round of model updates, a learner is first selected, either randomly or by following specific rules. All the other learners send their local models, possibly relayed via in-between learners, to the selected learner, who then performs model aggregation to update the global model. This approach requires coordination between the learners for aggregation learner selection for each round of model update. Another class of works adopts consensus-based algorithms, where the learners iteratively update their local models to reach consensus on the desired global model (Lu et al., 2020; Lalitha et al., 2019; Savazzi et al., 2020). At each iteration, the learners exchange their local models only with their one-hop neighbors. In contrast to the first approach, the consensus-based approach does not require coordination between the learners and hence is easier for practical implementation. However, all these works only consider a fixed communication topology and not applicable to an environment of high mobility where the communication topology may change between successive rounds of model aggregation. In addition, all the aforementioned works directly exchange local models between the learners and thus still suffer from model inference and inversion attacks.

In this work, we develop the first privacy-preserving consensus-based decentralized federated learning algorithm that considers mobility. This is closely related to the problem of privacy-preserving consensus, where the target is to protect the privacy of the participants’ initial states in the process of reaching consensus.

Existing works on privacy-preserving consensus can be categorized into four classes.

The first class of works uses perturbation-based approaches. An important branch of works in this class uses the technique of differential privacy (Huang et al., 2012; Zhao et al., 2018; He et al., 2020; Nozari et al., 2017). Differentially private schemes add random perturbations into individuals’ private data such that the participation of an individual cannot be inferred via perturbed data by an adversary with access to arbitrary auxiliary information (Dwork and Roth, 2014). Due to the usage of persistent random noises, there is a fundamental trade-off between privacy and utility (Geng and Viswanath, 2014; Lu and Zhu, 2019). The very recent work (Jeon et al., 2021) proposed a different perturbation-based approach, which used the number of iterations between two learners being in the same group (called gap therein) to control communication patterns among the learners. This approach also has a fundamental trade-off between privacy and utility.

The second class of works obfuscates exchanged data by adding decaying or correlated noises, which can guarantee consensus accuracy (Mo and Murray, 2017; Manitara and Hadjicostis, 2013; He et al., 2019; Gade and Vaidya, 2018a, b). This approach ensures that the private data cannot be uniquely determined. However, it still causes privacy leakage in the sense of information entropy of the private data, and the level of privacy leakage is determined by the magnitude of the noises (He et al., 2019).

The third class of works adopts the technique of homomorphic encryption (Lagendijk et al., 2013; Kogiso and Fujita, 2015; Shoukry et al., 2016; Lu and Zhu, 2018). Informally speaking, homomorphic encryption allows certain algebraic operations to be carried out on ciphertexts, thus generating an encrypted result which, when decrypted, matches the result of operations performed on plaintexts (Yi et al., 2014). Existing homomorphic encryption-based works require the existence of a centralized third party to carry out aggregation over ciphertexts. Hence, they are not applicable to the decentralized setting.

The fourth class of works leverages state decomposition to achieve privacy-preserving consensus in a decentralized setting (Ruan et al., 2019; Wang, 2019). In this approach, a scalar step size shared between two neighboring agents is constructed as a product of two scalar numbers, each randomly generated by one of the two agents and kept unknown to the other one. During the consensus algorithm, the agents exchange the product of their states and the randomly generated step size splits. Without knowing their step size splits, one agent cannot determine the values of the states of its neighbors. However, to guarantee convergence of the underlying consensus algorithm, the step size splits have to be restricted in a small interval. This will cause privacy degradation, as one can have a good estimate of the value of an agent’s state by knowing the admissible interval and observing the product of the state and the step size split.

Positioning our Research

To overcome the above limitations of existing works, we propose a new algorithm which integrates Shamir’s secret sharing (SSS) to achieve privacy-preserving consensus-based decentralized federated learning. Informally speaking, SSS distributes a secret among a group of participants, each of whom is allocated a share of the secret. As established by Shamir (Shamir, 1979), the secret can be reconstructed only when a sufficient number of shares are combined together, while a smaller number of shares contain no information of the secret. This technique has been widely applied to secure multiparty computation (SMC) on complete graphs (Cramer et al., 2015), where each participant can communicate with each other participant. Roughly speaking, each participant sends one share of its secret to each other participant. Each participant then computes an aggregation of the shares it receives from all the other participants. When a sufficient number of aggregated results are combined, the desired aggregation of the secrets of all the participants can be reconstructed. While these approaches work well in fully connected graphs, most real-world applications entail sparse graphs, e.g., optimal resource allocation in power systems (Cherukuri and Cortés, 2015), multi-robot formation control (Alonso-Mora et al., 2016), and distributed environmental monitoring (Aragues et al., 2013). In addition, in an environment of high mobility, the communication topology may change over time. For SMC over time-varying sparse graphs, where, at each round of computation, each participant can only communicate with its current neighbors, the above mechanisms cannot be applied. Few research has been conducted to SMC over sparse graphs. An exception is the recent work (Li and Christensen, 2019), which applied SSS to achieve privacy-preserving average consensus over sparse graphs. The work (Li and Christensen, 2019) has three major limitations. First, the approach of (Li and Christensen, 2019) needs to randomly activate one learner at each iteration, which requires coordination between the learners. Second, the approach of (Li and Christensen, 2019) can only deal with the case where each learner has at least two neighbors and the three learners form a fully connected graph. Third, rigorous correctness and privacy analysis are absent in (Li and Christensen, 2019). The paucity of SMC research on time-varying sparse graphs motivates our work to establish fundamental results therein.

1.3. Overview of Approach and Contributions

This paper considers the problem of privacy-preserving decentralized federated learning over a time-varying communication graph. Specifically, we consider the case where the global training model is updated as a weighted average of the learners’ local training models, and an average consensus algorithm is adopted to achieve decentralized aggregation. In each round of model aggregation, the Metropolis-Hastings method (Xiao et al., 2007) is applied to update the weighted adjacency matrix based on the current communication topology to ensure convergence of average consensus. To protect the privacy of local training models against semi-honest learners, the learners use the Shamir’s secret sharing scheme (Shamir, 1979) to distribute their local models to their one-hop neighbors. Upon receiving the shares from its neighbors, each learner updates its model by inputting the sum of the shares it holds to the consensus algorithm. The contributions of our work are fourfold.

  • •

    First, the proposed algorithm is the first that can achieve federated learning over a time-varying communication graph in a fully decentralized (without any coordination between the learners) and provably privacy-preserving manner.

  • •

    Second, in terms of privacy-preserving consensus, the proposed algorithm, for the first time, simultaneously achieves the following properties: (i) applicable to an arbitrary undirected connected communication graph without the need of a third party; (ii) perfect consensus (model aggregation) accuracy; (iii) no additional privacy leakage beyond the learners’ own inputs (the local training models) and outputs (the updated global models); (iv) no privacy-convergence tradeoff.

  • •

    Third, the correctness and privacy properties of the proposed algorithm are rigorously analyzed. In particular, the correctness analysis addresses new challenges brought by signed real-valued models and termination of consensus iteration, and the privacy analysis addresses new challenges in potential additional privacy leakage caused by consensus process and time-varying communication topology. Please refer to Section 4.2 for detailed discussions.

  • •

    Fourth, the correctness and computational efficiency of the proposed algorithm are demonstrated by a simulation on a federated learning framework using a real-world dataset.

1.4. Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 introduces the problem statement. Section 3 provides some necessary technical preliminaries. New challenges in algorithm design and analysis are identified in Section 4. The proposed algorithm is detailed in Section 5. Its correctness and privacy properties are analyzed in Section 6. In Section 7, case studies are presented to test the performance of the proposed algorithm. Conclusions and future works are found in Section 8.

2. Problem Statement

In this section, we first review the framework of centralized federated learning. Next, we formulate the problem of decentralized federated learning over a time-varying communication graph and identify its privacy issue. Subsequently, we introduce the adopted attacker model and privacy definition. Finally, we clarify the objectives of the paper.

2.1. Centralized Federated Learning

Consider a set of N𝑁N learners 𝒱≜{1,⋯,N}≜𝒱1⋯𝑁\mathcal{V}\triangleq\{1,\cdots,N\}. Each learner i𝑖i holds a set of mi∈ℕsubscript𝑚𝑖ℕm_{i}\in\mathbb{N} local data samples, denoted by Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. In federated learning, for the purpose of preserving privacy of individual Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}’s, in each round t𝑡t of model update, each learner i𝑖i first trains a local model θi(t)∈ℝnsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡superscriptℝ𝑛\theta_{i}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} over Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. In the centralized setting, as shown by Fig. 1, each learner i𝑖i uploads θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)} to a centralized server. 2.2. Decentralized Federated Learning over A Time-Varying Communication Graph

Decentralized model aggregation. As mentioned, in some scenarios, especially when the learners are geographically dispersed over a large area, there may not exist a centralized server that is connected to all the learners; please see Fig. 2 as an illustration. In such cases, the learners need to carry out the model aggregation Eq. (2) in a decentralized manner over the underlying communication graph between them.

Time-varying communication graph. In an environment of high mobility, the communication topology between the learners may vary between successive rounds of model aggregation as depicted in Fig. 3.

Denote 𝒢(t)=(𝒱,ℰ(t))superscript𝒢𝑡𝒱superscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}^{(t)}) as the communication graph between the learners during the t𝑡t-th round of model aggregation, where ℰ(t)⊆𝒱×𝒱superscriptℰ𝑡𝒱𝒱\mathcal{E}^{(t)}\subseteq\mathcal{V}\times\mathcal{V} is the set of communication links such that (i,j)(t)∈ℰ(t)superscript𝑖𝑗𝑡superscriptℰ𝑡(i,j)^{(t)}\in\mathcal{E}^{(t)} if and only if learner i𝑖i can receive messages from learner j𝑗j during the t𝑡t-th round of model aggregation. Denote 𝒩i(t)⊆𝒱superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡𝒱\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}\subseteq\mathcal{V} as the set of neighbors of learner i𝑖i in 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)}, i.e., 𝒩i(t)={j∈𝒱∖{i}:(i,j)(t)∈ℰ(t)}superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡conditional-set𝑗𝒱𝑖superscript𝑖𝑗𝑡superscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}=\{j\in\mathcal{V}\setminus\{i\}:(i,j)^{(t)}\in\mathcal{E}^{(t)}\}. Denote 𝒩¯i(t)=𝒩i(t)∪{i}superscriptsubscript¯𝒩𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡𝑖\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{i}^{(t)}=\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}\cup\{i\}. Throughout the paper, we have the following mild assumption on 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)}.

Assumption 2.1.

For any t∈ℕ𝑡ℕt\in\mathbb{N}, 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)} is undirected, connected, and time invariant within the t𝑡t-th round of model aggregation.

Privacy issue. During each round t𝑡t of model aggregation, for each learner i𝑖i, its local model θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)} must be kept private to itself, as breach of θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)} may enable an attacker to reconstruct learner i𝑖i’s local training data by inference or inversion attacks.

2.3. Attacker Model

We consider the semi-honest attacker model, i.e., an adversarial learner correctly follows the designed algorithm but attempts to use its received data to infer others’ private data ((Hazay and Lindell, 2010), pp-20). The semi-honest attacker model has been widely used in various applications, e.g., privacy-preserving linear programming, dataset process and consensus (Dreier and Kerschbaum, 2011; Freedman et al., 2004; Huang et al., 2012). We assume that the communication links between the learners are secure111Secure communication links can be enforced by cryptographic technologies such as encryption schemes..

2.4. Privacy Definition

As discussed above, our concerned problem is how all the learners can collaboratively compute the correct global model θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} without disclosing their local models θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)}’s to other learners. This is a secure multiparty computation (SMC) problem. Perfect secrecy, which will be adopted in this paper, is a standard privacy notion for SMC. Roughly speaking, an algorithm provides perfect secrecy if, after executing the algorithm, the adversarial entities only know their own inputs and outputs, but do not know anything beyond them, even if they have unlimited computing power (Shannon, 1949). It is worth noting that, unlike perturbation-related privacy notions, e.g., differential privacy, perfect secrecy does not induce the issue of utility-privacy tradeoff.

We next provide the formal definition of perfect secrecy in the general context of SMC, where, given a set of entities 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}, each entity i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} has a secret input xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} and aims to compute the value of fi​({xj}j∈𝒱)subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑗𝑗𝒱f_{i}(\{x_{j}\}_{j\in\mathcal{V}}). To do that, we need to introduce the notions of perfect indistinguishability and view. First, the following definition states that two distributions are perfectly indistinguishable if they follow the same distribution.

Definition 2.0 ((Cramer et al., 2015)).

Let 𝒳={𝒳​(κ)}κ∈ℕ𝒳subscript𝒳𝜅𝜅ℕ\mathcal{X}=\{\mathcal{X}(\kappa)\}_{\kappa\in\mathbb{N}} and 𝒴={𝒴​(κ)}κ∈ℕ𝒴subscript𝒴𝜅𝜅ℕ\mathcal{Y}=\{\mathcal{Y}(\kappa)\}_{\kappa\in\mathbb{N}} be two distribution ensembles, where, for each κ∈ℕ𝜅ℕ\kappa\in\mathbb{N}, 𝒳​(κ)𝒳𝜅\mathcal{X}(\kappa) and 𝒴​(κ)𝒴𝜅\mathcal{Y}(\kappa) are two random variables with the same probability space and the same range R​(κ)𝑅𝜅R(\kappa). We say that 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} are perfectly indistinguishable, denoted by 𝒳​≡p𝒴𝒳superscript𝑝𝒴\mathcal{X}\mathop{\equiv}\limits^{p}\mathcal{Y}, if the following holds

∑r∈R​(κ)|Pr⁡[𝒳​(κ)=r]−Pr⁡[𝒴​(κ)=r]|=0,∀κ∈ℕ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑟𝑅𝜅Pr𝒳𝜅𝑟Pr𝒴𝜅𝑟0for-all𝜅ℕ\displaystyle\sum_{r\in R(\kappa)}|\Pr[\mathcal{X}(\kappa)=r]-\Pr[\mathcal{Y}(\kappa)=r]|=0,\;\;\forall\kappa\in\mathbb{N}.

Next, we introduce the notion of view. Informally, the view of an entity is the set of all the messages the entity can see after the execution of the algorithm.

Definition 2.0 ((Cramer et al., 2015; Goldreich, 2004)).

Let ΠΠ\Pi be an algorithm for computing f={fi}i∈𝒱𝑓subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑖𝒱f=\{f_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}}. For an execution of ΠΠ\Pi on a joint input x={xi}i∈𝒱𝑥subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖𝒱x=\{x_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}}, the view of entity i𝑖i, denoted by VIEWiΠ​(x)superscriptsubscriptVIEW𝑖Π𝑥{\rm VIEW}_{i}^{\Pi}(x), is VIEWiΠ​(x)≜{xi,m1i,⋯,mtii}≜superscriptsubscriptVIEW𝑖Π𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑖⋯superscriptsubscript𝑚subscript𝑡𝑖𝑖{\rm VIEW}_{i}^{\Pi}(x)\triangleq\{x_{i},m_{1}^{i},\cdots,m_{t_{i}}^{i}\}, where tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} is the total number of messages received by entity i𝑖i, and for each ℓ∈{1,⋯,ti}ℓ1⋯subscript𝑡𝑖\ell\in\{1,\cdots,t_{i}\}, mℓisuperscriptsubscript𝑚ℓ𝑖m_{\ell}^{i} is the ℓℓ\ell-th message it receives.

This provides the basis to define perfect secrecy.

Definition 2.0 ((Cramer et al., 2015)).

Let ΠΠ\Pi be an algorithm for computing f={fi}i∈𝒱𝑓subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑖𝒱f=\{f_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}}. Given a joint input x={xi}i∈𝒱𝑥subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖𝒱x=\{x_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}}, denote the joint view of the entities in a set ℐ⊆𝒱ℐ𝒱\mathcal{I}\subseteq\mathcal{V} by VIEWℐΠ​(x)superscriptsubscriptVIEWℐΠ𝑥{\rm VIEW}_{\mathcal{I}}^{\Pi}(x). Let 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} be the set of adversarial learners. We say that ΠΠ\Pi provides perfect secrecy against 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} if there exists a probabilistic polynomial-time algorithm S𝑆S, such that for any admissible x𝑥x, it holds that

(3) S​(𝒜,{xi}i∈𝒜,{fi}i∈𝒜)​≡pVIEW𝒜Π​(x).𝑆𝒜subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖𝒜subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑖𝒜superscript𝑝superscriptsubscriptVIEW𝒜Π𝑥\displaystyle S(\mathcal{A},\{x_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{A}},\{f_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{A}})\mathop{\equiv}\limits^{p}{\rm VIEW}_{\mathcal{A}}^{\Pi}(x).

The condition Eq. (3) implies that whatever can been seen by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} after the execution of ΠΠ\Pi can be simulated by an algorithm S𝑆S using only 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}’s own inputs and outputs, and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} cannot distinguish S​(𝒜,{xi}i∈𝒜,{fi}i∈𝒜)𝑆𝒜subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖𝒜subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖𝑖𝒜S(\mathcal{A},\{x_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{A}},\{f_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{A}}) and VIEW𝒜Π​(x)superscriptsubscriptVIEW𝒜Π𝑥{\rm VIEW}_{\mathcal{A}}^{\Pi}(x) even if it has unlimited computing power. In other words, the execution of ΠΠ\Pi does not provide 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} any additional information beyond what it must know, i.e., 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}’s own inputs and outputs.

2.5. Design Objectives

In this paper, we aim to design a privacy-preserving decentralized algorithm for the model aggregation Eq. (2) over a time-varying sparse communication graph satisfying Assumption 2.1, such that the following properties are simultaneously guaranteed:

  • •

    Correctness: For every round t∈ℕ𝑡ℕt\in\mathbb{N}, all the learners derive the correct global model θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} given by Eq. (2).

  • •

    Privacy: The proposed algorithm protects the privacy of benign learners’ local models θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)}’s against semi-honest learners in the sense of perfect secrecy.

3. Technical Preliminaries

In this paper, we achieve the objectives stated in Section 2.5 by integrating average consensus and Shamir’s secret sharing. This section provides necessary technical preliminaries of the two techniques.

3.1. Consensus-based Decentralized Model Aggregation

Average consensus is an effective method to achieve decentralized aggregation over sparse communication graphs. This subsection first provides preliminaries on average consensus-based decentralized model aggregation, then introduces the Metropolis-Hastings method to deal with time-varying communication graphs. More detailed discussions can be found in (Xiao et al., 2007; Xiao and Boyd, 2003; Schwarz et al., 2014).

Average consensus. Roughly speaking, this method enables a set of entities over a sparse connected communication graph, each with an initial state, to iteratively interact with their neighbors and update their states, such that all the entities’ states will asymptotically converge to the average of their initial states.

To apply the average consensus method, for each round t𝑡t of model aggregation, the communication graph 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)} needs to be equipped with a weighted adjacency matrix A(t)=[ai​j(t)]∈ℝN×Nsuperscript𝐴𝑡delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁𝑁A^{(t)}=[a_{ij}^{(t)}]\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N} such that ai​j(t)>0superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡0a_{ij}^{(t)}>0 if (i,j)(t)∈ℰ(t)superscript𝑖𝑗𝑡superscriptℰ𝑡(i,j)^{(t)}\in\mathcal{E}^{(t)} and ai​j(t)=0superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡0a_{ij}^{(t)}=0 otherwise. For now, we assume that A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} is given and provide the average consensus update rule and its convergence property. The construction of A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} will be illustrated afterwords.

With A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)}, to carry out the model aggregation Eq. (2) in a decentralized manner, each learner i𝑖i iteratively constructs a sequence of weighted local models {θ¯i(t)​(k)}superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘\{\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(k)\}, where k𝑘k is the iteration index for the consensus algorithm below, such that θ¯i(t)​(0)=wi​θi(t)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0)=w_{i}\theta_{i}^{(t)}, and the update rule is given by

The following lemma provides a sufficient and necessary condition for reaching average consensus.

Lemma 3.0 ((Xiao and Boyd, 2003)).

With A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} in each round t𝑡t of model aggregation, the learners can achieve asymptotic average consensus Eq. (5) by the update rule Eq. (4) from any initial joint state θ¯(t)​(0)superscript¯𝜃𝑡0\bar{\theta}^{(t)}(0) if and only if the following conditions are simultaneously satisfied

where 1Nsubscript1𝑁1_{N} is the N𝑁N-dimensional column vector with all ones, and ρ​(⋅)𝜌⋅\rho(\cdot) denotes the spectral radius222The spectral radius of a square matrix is the largest absolute value of its eigenvalues. of a square matrix.

The intuition of Lemma 3.1 lies in that condition (6) guarantees asymptotic consensus, while conditions (7) and (8) ensure that the convergence is to the desired average point 1N​∑j∈𝒱θ¯j(t)​(0)1𝑁subscript𝑗𝒱superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑗𝑡0\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{V}}\bar{\theta}_{j}^{(t)}(0).

The next question is how to construct A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} that satisfies all the conditions (6)–(8). One efficient approach is the Metropolis-Hastings method, illustrated next.

Metropolis-Hastings method. For a time-varying communication graph, the Metropolis-Hastings method (Xiao et al., 2007) can be applied to update A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} to ensure asymptotic average consensus. In particular, for each round t𝑡t, based on its current local communication topology, each learner i𝑖i constructs weights ai​j(t)superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡a_{ij}^{(t)}’s for all j∈𝒩¯i(t)𝑗superscriptsubscript¯𝒩𝑖𝑡j\in\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{i}^{(t)} as follows

(9) ai​j(t)={1max⁡{|𝒩i(t)|,|𝒩j(t)|}+1if ​j∈𝒩i(t)1−∑j∈𝒩i(t)1max⁡{|𝒩i(t)|,|𝒩j(t)|}+1if ​j=i,superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡cases1superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑗𝑡1if 𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑗𝑡1if 𝑗𝑖\displaystyle a_{ij}^{(t)}=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{\max\{|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}|,|\mathcal{N}_{j}^{(t)}|\}+1}&\text{if }j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}\\ 1-\sum\limits_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}}\frac{1}{\max\{|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}|,|\mathcal{N}_{j}^{(t)}|\}+1}&\text{if }j=i,\end{cases}

where |⋅||\cdot| denotes the cardinality of a set.

As an illustrative example, in Fig. 4, the figure on the left shows the communication topology between four learners, and the matrix on the right is the corresponding weighted adjacency matrix A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} constructed by (9).

The following lemma states that A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} constructed by (9) satisfies all the conditions of Lemma 3.1.

Lemma 3.0 ((Schwarz et al., 2014)).

Under Assumption 2.1, in each round t𝑡t, if A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} is constructed by (9), then the conditions (6)–(8) are all satisfied.

By Lemmas 3.1 and 3.2, the update rule (4) with A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} constructed by (9) ensures asymptotic average consensus (5). Notice that in running both (4) and (9), each learner only needs information from its neighbors. Hence, the aforementioned consensus-based method realizes the model aggregation (2) over a time-varying communication graph in a fully decentralized manner.

On the other hand, in implementing (4), each learner i𝑖i directly sends its state θ¯i(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(k) at each consensus iteration k𝑘k to its neighbors. This causes the breach of its initial state θ¯i(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0) and of its local training model θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)}. Hence, the privacy issue remains to be addressed for the implementation of (4).

3.2. Shamir’s Secret Sharing

In the paper, we will adopt SSS to facilitate privacy in the implementation of (4). This subsection provides some preliminaries on how to use SSS to distribute a secret over a finite set of entities. More detailed discussions can be found in (Shamir, 1979; Cramer et al., 2015).

Shares generation. To distribute a secret s𝑠s over a set of entities 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}, SSS uses a polynomial of degree smaller than |𝒱|𝒱|\mathcal{V}| to generate |𝒱|𝒱|\mathcal{V}| shares of s𝑠s, one share for one entity of 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V}. Formally, given a prime number p>|𝒱|𝑝𝒱p>|\mathcal{V}| and a positive integer τ<|𝒱|𝜏𝒱\tau<|\mathcal{V}|, a secret s∈ℤp𝑠subscriptℤ𝑝s\in\mathbb{Z}_{p} is split into |𝒱|𝒱|\mathcal{V}| shares {ℋi}i∈𝒱subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑖𝑖𝒱\{\mathcal{H}^{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}} by Algorithm 1. In the algorithm, p𝑝p is the parameter to set the underlying finite field for SSS, and τ𝜏\tau is the degree of the polynomial used to generate shares of s𝑠s. After shares generation, the share ℋisuperscriptℋ𝑖\mathcal{H}^{i} is sent to entity i𝑖i for all i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V}.

Reconstruction. As given by the following lemma, the secret s𝑠s can be reconstructed by collecting arbitrary τ+1𝜏1\tau+1 or more shares via the technique of Lagrange interpolation. This property directly follows the fact that a polynomial of degree τ𝜏\tau can be uniquely determined by any τ+1𝜏1\tau+1 or more points of the polynomial.

Lemma 3.0 ((Cramer et al., 2015)).

Let (s,p,τ,𝒱)𝑠𝑝𝜏𝒱(s,p,\tau,\mathcal{V}) and {ℋi}i∈𝒱subscriptsuperscriptℋ𝑖𝑖𝒱\{\mathcal{H}^{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}} be a set of inputs and corresponding outputs of Algorithm 1, respectively. Then for any set 𝒞⊆𝒱𝒞𝒱\mathcal{C}\subseteq\mathcal{V} with |𝒞|≥τ+1𝒞𝜏1|\mathcal{C}|\geq\tau+1, s𝑠s can be reconstructed as s=∑i∈𝒞ℋi​δ𝒞,imodp𝑠modulosubscript𝑖𝒞superscriptℋ𝑖subscript𝛿𝒞𝑖𝑝s=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{C}}\mathcal{H}^{i}\delta_{\mathcal{C},i}\mod p, where

(10) δ𝒞,i=∏j∈𝒞,j≠ijj−imodp,∀i∈𝒞.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛿𝒞𝑖modulosubscriptproductformulae-sequence𝑗𝒞𝑗𝑖𝑗𝑗𝑖𝑝for-all𝑖𝒞\displaystyle\delta_{\mathcal{C},i}=\prod_{j\in\mathcal{C},j\neq i}\frac{j}{j-i}\mod p,\;\forall i\in\mathcal{C}.

Privacy. The privacy property of SSS is given by the following lemma, which states that the collection of any τ𝜏\tau or less shares generated by Algorithm 1 contains no information of s𝑠s. This property follows the fact that it takes at least τ+1𝜏1\tau+1 points to define a polynomial of degree τ𝜏\tau.

Lemma 3.0 ((Cramer et al., 2015)).

SSS provides perfect secrecy against any set ℐ⊆𝒱ℐ𝒱\mathcal{I}\subseteq\mathcal{V} such that |ℐ|≤τℐ𝜏|\mathcal{I}|\leq\tau.

4. New Challenges in Algorithm Design and Analysis

In this section, we first provide the high-level idea of algorithm design based on integrating SSS with average consensus. After that, we identify new challenges to a trivial integration brought by the nature of the concerned problem setting.

4.1. High-level description

As mentioned, in this paper, we achieve privacy-preserving decentralized federated learning by integrating SSS with the average consensus update rule (4). Informally speaking, to protect the privacy of θ¯i(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0), each learner i𝑖i uses a new state si(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0s_{i}^{(t)}(0) as the initial state in executing (4). The new states si(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0s_{i}^{(t)}(0)’s need to simultaneously satisfy:

  • •

    Correctness: The average consensus point under the initial states si(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0s_{i}^{(t)}(0)’s is or can be used to locally derive the desired global model θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)}.

  • •

    Privacy: The observation and the derivation process of si(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0s_{i}^{(t)}(0)’s do not disclose any information of θ¯i(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0)’s.

To this end, the learners generate si(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0s_{i}^{(t)}(0)’s via SSS, as informally illustrated as follows. First, by Algorithm 1, each learner i𝑖i uses a polynomial of degree |𝒩i(t)|superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}| to generate |𝒩i(t)|+1superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡1|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}|+1 shares of θ¯i(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0), distributes |𝒩i(t)|superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}| shares to its corresponding neighbors, while keeping one share private to itself. After the exchange of shares, each learner i𝑖i aggregates the |𝒩i(t)|superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}| shares received from its neighbors and the one share generated and held secretly by itself to form si(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0s_{i}^{(t)}(0), and uses it as the initial state in executing (4).

We next informally discuss the correctness and privacy intuitions of the above procedure.

  • •

    Correctness: By the convergence property of (4), all the learners can derive ∑i∈𝒱si(t)​(0)subscript𝑖𝒱superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}s_{i}^{(t)}(0), which is the aggregation of all the shares of all the learners’ local models {θ¯i(t)​(0)}i∈𝒱subscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0𝑖𝒱\{\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0)\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}}. Notice that, by the reconstruction property of SSS, each individual θ¯i(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0) can be reconstructed by aggregating all of its |𝒩i(t)|+1superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡1|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}|+1 shares. Hence, ∑i∈𝒱si(t)​(0)subscript𝑖𝒱superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}s_{i}^{(t)}(0) can be used to reconstruct ∑i∈𝒱θ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖𝒱superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0), which is the global model θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)}.

  • •

    Privacy: By the privacy property of SSS, θ¯i(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0) is perfectly secret if and only if not all of its |𝒩i(t)|+1superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡1|\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}|+1 shares are known to the adversarial learners. It can be perceived that a necessary condition for this is that learner i𝑖i has at least one benign neighbor.

4.2. New Challenges

The last subsection presents a high-level framework based on the integration of the consensus method and SSS. However, for the concerned problem setting, a trivial integration is far from enough. In this subsection, we identify new challenges in terms of design and analysis which are critical for establishing rigorous correctness and privacy properties. Besides, we also briefly illustrate how these challenges are addressed in this paper, while the details are provided in Section 5 and Section 6.

There are four major challenges, as detailed next. Specifically, the first two are due to the real-valued setting of our problem of interest, and bring new challenges to correctness guarantee. The last two stem from more complicated information flow caused by the iterative nature of the consensus process as well as time-varying communication topology between successive training rounds, and bring new challenges to privacy analysis.

(i) Signed real-valued models. The standard SSS scheme involves modular operations and has to be implemented over non-negative integers. However, the training models in federated learning usually take signed real values. To address this mismatch, we propose a transformation between non-negative integers and signed real numbers (given by (17)). Roughly speaking, the learners transform their local models into integers and apply the procedure described in the last subsection. After the final non-negative integer-valued consensus model is derived, each agent then uses the proposed transformation to turn it back to a signed real-valued model. If the parameter p𝑝p in Algorithm 1 is sufficiently large (a sufficient lower bound of p𝑝p is provided by (18)), then it is guaranteed that the transformed real-valued model is the correct global model.

(ii) Termination of consensus iteration. As mentioned in the last paragraph, the learners input integer-valued models into the procedure described in Section 4.1. Hence, theoretically, the asymptotic consensus result is a non-negative integer-valued model. To reconstruct the global model by SSS, before the integer-to-real transformation, this model needs to be exerted a modulo p𝑝p operation (please refer to Lemma 3.3 and (14)). However, since the convergence of the consensus update rule is only asymptotic and the weights ai​j(t)superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡a_{ij}^{(t)}’s in (4) are decimals, the intermediate results of (4) may also be decimals. Due to the subsequent modulo p𝑝p operation, even if the terminating result is close to the theoretical integer-valued result, there could be a large deviation in the remainder after the modulo operation. To see this, consider the case where the terminating result is 99.4 and rounded to 99, the theoretical result is 100, and the value of p𝑝p is 50. After the modulo p𝑝p operation, the remainders for the terminating result and the theoretical result are 49 and 0, respectively. This shows that, compared to usual consensus applications, we need a more careful control on the termination condition. To address this challenge, we identify a sufficient lower bound of the number of consensus iterations (given by (19)) that guarantees that the absolute difference between the terminating and the theoretical results is strictly smaller than 0.5, and hence the result after the rounding operation is just the theoretical result.

(iii) Privacy leakage during consensus process. For the standard SSS-based secure sum computation over a complete communication graph, each entity receives all the other entities’ shares just once and then performs an aggregation. For this standard scheme, as long as there is an honest majority (more specifically, the number of adversarial entities is no greater than the degree of the polynomial used to generated shares), then the adversarial entities cannot gain anything beyond the sum of all the entities’ private inputs. However, in our case, since the communication graph is sparse, secure sum computation is further facilitated by a consensus process, where the shares need to be iteratively exchanged and aggregated according to the consensus update rule and the underlying communication topology. Such multiple rounds of communications may cause additional privacy leakage, e.g., partial sum (the sum of the local models of a subset of learners). This indicates that new privacy analysis is needed for the consensus process. To address this challenge, we identify a graph-oriented condition, which can be used to characterize the view of the adversarial learners throughout the whole consensus process (please refer to Lemma 6.2).

(iv) Privacy property under time-varying communication topology. Besides the privacy issue caused by the consensus process, the time-varying communication topology further induces new challenges to privacy preservation. Specifically, due to time-varying communication topology, one-shot privacy preservation (privacy for one round of training) is not enough. Instead, we must establish a privacy condition with respect to the evolution of the communication topology. To address this challenge, we further extend the graph-oriented condition mentioned in the last paragraph to derive a sufficient and necessary condition under which perfect secrecy is achieved throughout the evolution of the communication topology (please refer to Theorem 6.3).

5. Privacy-Preserving Decentralized Algorithm Design

In this section, the proposed privacy-preserving decentralized federated learning algorithm is developed. First, we illustrate the design details and highlight how the challenges identified in the last section are addressed. A summarize of the whole design is provided afterwards.

5.1. Design Details

In this paper, we use finite precision to cope with transformations between real numbers and integers. In particular, throughout the paper, the precision level is set by σ∈ℕ𝜎ℕ\sigma\in\mathbb{N}, that is, for any real number, only the first σ𝜎\sigma fraction digits are kept while rest ones are dropped.

The overall design has three phases, secret shares generation of local models, consensus iteration, and global model reconstruction. The design is detailed next.

Secret shares generation of local models. All the learners first agree on a positive prime number p𝑝p, which can be realized by a maximum consensus algorithm offline. We next fix a training round t𝑡t and a learner i𝑖i, and illustrate the secret shares generation of θ¯i(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0).

A rigorous sufficient lower bound of p𝑝p is given by (18) in Section 6.1.

5.2. Overall Algorithm Design Summary

Algorithm 2 presents our overall design, with its operational steps summarized next.

At step 1, all the learners agree on three parameters. In particular, p𝑝p is the parameter to set the finite field for SSS, T𝑇T is the number of training rounds, and K𝐾K is the number of consensus iterations in each training round. As mentioned in the last subsection, these parameters can be realized by a maximum consensus algorithm offline. At step 2, each learner i𝑖i sets the initial model θi1,0superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖10\theta_{i}^{1,0} for its local training in the first round. At step 3, each learner i𝑖i trains its local model θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)} by ℱisubscriptℱ𝑖\mathcal{F}_{i} with its initial model θit,0superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡0\theta_{i}^{t,0} and dataset Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. At step 4, based on its current local communication topology, each learner i𝑖i constructs its local weights ai​j(t)superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑡a_{ij}^{(t)} in A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} by the Metropolis-Hastings method. At steps 5–8, each learner i𝑖i applies SSS to generate shares of 10σ​θ¯i(t)​(0)superscript10𝜎superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡010^{\sigma}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0) and distributes the shares {𝒮ij​(t)}j∈𝒩i(t)subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒮𝑖𝑗𝑡𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡\{\mathcal{S}_{i}^{j(t)}\}_{j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}} to its neighbors. At step 9, each learner i𝑖i constructs the initial state si(t)​(0)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡0s_{i}^{(t)}(0) for the consensus iteration as the sum of all the shares assigned to it. At step 10, each learner i𝑖i updates its state si(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑡𝑘s_{i}^{(t)}(k) by the average consensus algorithm with A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)}. At steps 11–13, each learner i𝑖i transforms the consensus model back to a signed real-valued model θ~i(t)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑡\tilde{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}. At step 14, each learner i𝑖i sets θ~i(t)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑡\tilde{\theta}_{i}^{(t)} as the initial model θi(t+1,0)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡10\theta_{i}^{(t+1,0)} for its local training in round t+1𝑡1t+1.

6. Correctness and Privacy Analysis

This section establishes the correctness and privacy properties for Algorithm 2.

6.1. Correctness Analysis

The correctness property of Algorithm 2 is established by the following theorem, which states that each learner i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} derives the correct aggregated global model θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)} for each round t𝑡t.

This completes the proof.  

Remark 6.1.

By the analysis above, we can see that perfect average consensus is reached after a finite K𝐾K number of iterations. We note that this finite average consensus is only due to the usage of finite precision. By (18) and (19), we can see that the bound of K𝐾K increases with the value of the precision level σ𝜎\sigma. When σ𝜎\sigma tends to infinity, then K𝐾K also tends to infinity, which indicates asymptotic average consensus.

6.2. Privacy Analysis

To develop the privacy property of Algorithm 2, we first introduce the following notions.

Let ℬℬ\mathcal{B} and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} be the sets of benign and adversarial learners, respectively. Notice that ℬ∪𝒜=𝒱ℬ𝒜𝒱\mathcal{B}\cup\mathcal{A}=\mathcal{V}. Given any round t∈{1,⋯,T}𝑡1⋯𝑇t\in\{1,\cdots,T\}, we say that a subset ℬs⊆ℬsubscriptℬ𝑠ℬ\mathcal{B}_{s}\subseteq\mathcal{B} of benign learners are surrounded by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)} if there exists a connected subgraph of 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)} consisting of all the benign learners in ℬssubscriptℬ𝑠\mathcal{B}_{s} but no benign learners in ℬ\ℬs\ℬsubscriptℬ𝑠\mathcal{B}\backslash\mathcal{B}_{s} and no adversarial learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, such that for each i∈ℬs𝑖subscriptℬ𝑠i\in\mathcal{B}_{s}, it holds that 𝒩i(t)∩(ℬ\ℬs)=∅superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖𝑡\ℬsubscriptℬ𝑠\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(t)}\cap(\mathcal{B}\backslash\mathcal{B}_{s})=\emptyset. That is, for every benign learner in ℬssubscriptℬ𝑠\mathcal{B}_{s}, all of its benign neighbors, if any, are inside ℬssubscriptℬ𝑠\mathcal{B}_{s}. Let ℬ^(t)superscript^ℬ𝑡\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)} be the set containing all such sets ℬssubscriptℬ𝑠\mathcal{B}_{s}’s in round t𝑡t, i.e., ℬ^(t)={ℬs⊆ℬ:the​learners​in​ℬs​are​surrounded​by​𝒜​in​𝒢(t)}superscript^ℬ𝑡conditional-setsubscriptℬ𝑠ℬthelearnersinsubscriptℬ𝑠aresurroundedby𝒜insuperscript𝒢𝑡\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)}=\{\mathcal{B}_{s}\subseteq\mathcal{B}:{\rm the\;learners\;in\;}\mathcal{B}_{s}{\rm\;are\;surrounded\;by\;}\mathcal{A}{\rm\;in\;}\mathcal{G}^{(t)}\}.

First, the following lemma establishes the view of the adversarial learners throughout the execution of Algorithm 2.

Based on Lemma 6.2, the perfect secrecy property of Algorithm 2 is established by the following theorem. It states that the algorithm provides perfect secrecy if and only if all the benign learners in ℬℬ\mathcal{B} form a connected subgraph within themselves for every round t𝑡t. In other words, there is no proper subset of benign learners that are surrounded by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in any round t𝑡t.

Theorem 6.3.

Algorithm 2 provides perfect secrecy against 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} if and only if ℬ^(t)={ℬ}superscript^ℬ𝑡ℬ\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)}=\{\mathcal{B}\} for all t∈{1,⋯,T}𝑡1⋯𝑇t\in\{1,\cdots,T\}.

Proof: By Definition 2.3, if the algorithm provides perfect secrecy against 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, then, in each round t𝑡t, the learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} must only gain the value of ∑i∈𝒱θ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖𝒱superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0). Notice that the learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} know the sum of their own local models, i.e., ∑i∈𝒜θ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖𝒜superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{A}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0). Hence, they definitely can infer the sum of all the benign learners’ local models ∑i∈ℬθ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖ℬsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0) by computing ∑i∈ℬθ¯i(t)​(0)=∑i∈𝒱θ¯i(t)​(0)−∑i∈𝒜θ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖ℬsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0subscript𝑖𝒱superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0subscript𝑖𝒜superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0)=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0)-\sum_{i\in\mathcal{A}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0). Therefore, the algorithm is perfectly secret if and only if the learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} do not gain anything about {θ¯i(t)​(0)}i∈ℬsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0𝑖ℬ\{\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0)\}_{i\in\mathcal{B}} beyond the value of ∑i∈ℬθ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖ℬsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0) for all t∈{1,⋯,T}𝑡1⋯𝑇t\in\{1,\cdots,T\}.

First, if ℬ^(t)≠{ℬ}superscript^ℬ𝑡ℬ\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)}\neq\{\mathcal{B}\} for some round t𝑡t, then there exists a proper subset ℬs⊊ℬsubscriptℬ𝑠ℬ\mathcal{B}_{s}\subsetneq\mathcal{B} of benign learners such that ℬs∈ℬ^(t)subscriptℬ𝑠superscript^ℬ𝑡\mathcal{B}_{s}\in\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)}. By Lemma 6.2, the learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} can then obtain the value of ∑i∈ℬsθ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖subscriptℬ𝑠superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}_{s}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0), which is an additional piece of information beyond ∑i∈ℬθ¯i(t)​(0)subscript𝑖ℬsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0). Hence, the algorithm is not perfectly secret.

Next, consider the case where ℬ^(t)={ℬ}superscript^ℬ𝑡ℬ\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)}=\{\mathcal{B}\} for all t∈{1,⋯,T}𝑡1⋯𝑇t\in\{1,\cdots,T\}. By Lemma 6.2, in each round t𝑡t, the learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} gain nothing beyond the value of {∑i∈ℬsθ¯i(t)​(0)}ℬs∈ℬ^(t)=∑i∈ℬθ¯i(t)​(0)subscriptsubscript𝑖subscriptℬ𝑠superscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0subscriptℬ𝑠superscript^ℬ𝑡subscript𝑖ℬsuperscriptsubscript¯𝜃𝑖𝑡0\{\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}_{s}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0)\}_{\mathcal{B}_{s}\in\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)}}=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}}\bar{\theta}_{i}^{(t)}(0). Therefore, the algorithm provides perfect secrecy against 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. This completes the proof.  

Remark 6.2.

The condition of Theorem 6.3, i.e., ℬ^(t)={ℬ}superscript^ℬ𝑡ℬ\hat{\mathcal{B}}^{(t)}=\{\mathcal{B}\} for all t∈{1,⋯,T}𝑡1⋯𝑇t\in\{1,\cdots,T\}, ensures the strong privacy property of perfect secrecy such that the adversarial learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} do not even know partial sums of the local models of any proper subset of the benign learners. It would be worth noting that, if we only target on the weaker privacy property such that each individual benign learner’s local model is not disclosed to the learners in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, then by Lemma 6.2, the condition becomes that each benign learner has at least one benign neighbor in 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)} for all t∈{1,⋯,T}𝑡1⋯𝑇t\in\{1,\cdots,T\}.

7. Performance Evaluation

This section tests the performance of Algorithm 2 by a federated learning framework with a real-world dataset.

7.1. Simulation Setup

Environment. The simulation environment is as follows. On the hardware side, the simulation is performed on a Lenovo ThinkPad laptop computer with Intel(R) Core(TM) i5-1135G7 CPU at 2.40 GHz. On the software side, the simulation is performed on MATLAB R2021b.

Dataset. The dataset we use in the simulation is MNIST (Deng, 2012), which is a large-scale dataset of handwritten digits that is broadly used for training various image processing systems. It has a training set of 60000 samples and a testing set of 10000 samples. Each data sample has 784 features and 1 label. The simulation uses the set of 60000 training data samples and evenly distributes them over 100 learners. For each data sample, the label is removed. Hence, each learner has 600 local training data samples and each data sample consists of 784 features.

ML model for local training. In each round t𝑡t, each learner i𝑖i uses an autoencoder to train its local model θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)}. An autoencoder is an unsupervised learning algorithm for neural networks to learn efficient codings of unlabeled data. It has two parts, an encoder that compresses the input into a latent space representation, and a decoder that maps this representation to a reconstruction of the input. With hℎh hidden layers, in each round t𝑡t, each learner i𝑖i’s encoder consists of an h×784ℎ784h\times 784 weight matrix Wi​(e)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑒𝑡W_{i(e)}^{(t)} and an h×1ℎ1h\times 1 bias vector bi​(e)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑒𝑡b_{i(e)}^{(t)}, and its decoder consists of a 784×h784ℎ784\times h weight matrix Wi​(d)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑡W_{i(d)}^{(t)} and a 784×17841784\times 1 bias vector bi​(d)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑑𝑡b_{i(d)}^{(t)}. The local model θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)} is constructed by stacking all the entries of Wi​(e)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑒𝑡W_{i(e)}^{(t)}, bi​(e)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑒𝑡b_{i(e)}^{(t)}, Wi​(d)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑡W_{i(d)}^{(t)} and bi​(d)(t)superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑑𝑡b_{i(d)}^{(t)} into a single column vector. Therefore, the dimension of θi(t)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡\theta_{i}^{(t)} is n=h×784+h+784×h+784=1569​h+784𝑛ℎ784ℎ784ℎ7841569ℎ784n=h\times 784+h+784\times h+784=1569h+784.

7.2. Simulation Results

In the simulation, we set σ=2𝜎2\sigma=2, p=1020431𝑝1020431p=1020431, and T=6𝑇6T=6. For the correctness verification, we set K=10𝐾10K=10. We have verified that the conditions given by (18) and (19) are both satisfied.

We first verify the correctness property of Algorithm 2. Here we use one hidden layer for each learner’s local training, which leads to n=2353𝑛2353n=2353. To simulate time-varying communication topology, for each round t𝑡t, an arbitrary communication topology satisfying Assumption 2.1 is applied. First, we verify correct average consensus at each training round. To this end, we pick an arbitrary l∈{1,⋯,n}𝑙1⋯𝑛l\in\{1,\cdots,n\} for the illustration. In each training round t𝑡t, for each i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} and each k∈{0,⋯,K}𝑘0⋯𝐾k\in\{0,\cdots,K\}, with si​l(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑘s_{il}^{(t)}(k) generated by (13), we construct zi​l(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑘z_{il}^{(t)}(k) by (14) with si​l(t)​(K)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑙𝑡𝐾s_{il}^{(t)}(K) replaced by si​l(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑘s_{il}^{(t)}(k), and then construct θ~i​l(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑘\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}(k) by (17) with zi​l(t)superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑙𝑡z_{il}^{(t)} replaced by zi​l(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑘z_{il}^{(t)}(k). Notice that zi​l(t)=zi​l(t)​(K)superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑙𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖𝑙𝑡𝐾z_{il}^{(t)}=z_{il}^{(t)}(K) and θ~i​l(t)=θ~i​l(t)​(K)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡𝐾\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}=\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}(K). For each t=1,⋯,6𝑡1⋯6t=1,\cdots,6, the trajectories of θ~i​l(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑘\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}(k) for all i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} are sequentially shown in Fig. 5. We can see that, for each round t𝑡t, all the 100 trajectories converge to a same value. Indeed, for each t=1,⋯,6𝑡1⋯6t=1,\cdots,6, we have verified that all the 100 trajectories converge to the correct value of the desired global sum θl​(t)=∑i∈𝒱wi​θi​l(t)superscript𝜃𝑙𝑡subscript𝑖𝒱subscript𝑤𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡\theta^{l(t)}=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{V}}w_{i}\theta_{il}^{(t)}, i.e., at k=K=10𝑘𝐾10k=K=10, θ~i​l(t)​(10)=θl​(t)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡10superscript𝜃𝑙𝑡\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}(10)=\theta^{l(t)} for all i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V}. To better show this, we pick an arbitrary i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} and plot the trajectories of θ~i​l(t)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)} and |θ~i​l(t)−θl​(t)|superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑙𝑡|\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}-\theta^{l(t)}| for three arbitrarily picked l𝑙l’s (l=1569,2033,2040𝑙156920332040l=1569,2033,2040); as shown by Fig. 6 (notice that these two trajectories are the same for all learners as θ~i​l(t)​(k)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡𝑘\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}(k)’s for all i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} converge to a same value). In each sub-figure of Fig. 6, the red dashed curve is the trajectory of |θ~i​l(t)−θl​(t)|superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑙𝑡|\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}-\theta^{l(t)}|, i.e., the absolute difference between the consensus value and the ground-truth value at each round t𝑡t. This verifies that the global model computed by Algorithm 2 is correct under time-varying communication topology. The blue solid curve in Fig. 6 is the trajectory of θ~i​l(t)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙𝑡\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(t)}. It illustrates the convergence of the plain federated learning scheme. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 together verify the correctness property of Algorithm 2.

We next use simulations to show the impact of the communication topology on the convergence rate of the consensus process. It is well known that the convergence rate is dependent on the overall connectivity degree of the communication topology. Roughly speaking, for a given number of learners, a denser communication topology usually exhibits a higher convergence rate. More specifically, the second largest eigenvalue of the underlying weighted adjacency matrix (A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)}) is an important indicator of topology connectivity. In our problem setting, a smaller second largest eigenvalue of A(t)superscript𝐴𝑡A^{(t)} indicates a denser connectivity of the communication topology and a better convergence rate (Olshevsky and Tsitsiklis, 2009). To visually show the impact of the communication topology on the convergence rate, for the same l𝑙l as above, we generate the sequence of {θ~i​l(1)​(k)}i∈𝒱subscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙1𝑘𝑖𝒱\{\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(1)}(k)\}_{i\in\mathcal{V}} under six communication topologies. The first one is the complete topology, i.e., (i,j)∈ℰ(1)𝑖𝑗superscriptℰ1(i,j)\in\mathcal{E}^{(1)} for all i,j∈𝒱𝑖𝑗𝒱i,j\in\mathcal{V} with i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. The second one is a sparse topology where each learner has 40 neighbors. The third and fourth ones are sparser topologies where each learner has 20 and 10 neighbors, respectively. The fifth one is the star topology, i.e., there exists one learner i𝑖i such that j∈𝒩i(1)𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒩𝑖1j\in\mathcal{N}_{i}^{(1)} for all j∈𝒱\{i}𝑗\𝒱𝑖j\in\mathcal{V}\backslash\{i\}, while (j,ℓ)∉ℰ(1)𝑗ℓsuperscriptℰ1(j,\ell)\notin\mathcal{E}^{(1)} for any j,ℓ∈𝒱\{i}𝑗ℓ\𝒱𝑖j,\ell\in\mathcal{V}\backslash\{i\}. The sixth one is the line topology, i.e., the connection of the learners forms a line. Intuitively, the six topologies have descending connectivity degrees. Indeed, their corresponding matrix A(1)superscript𝐴1A^{(1)} have ascending second largest eigenvalues: 0, 0.3259, 0.8181, 0.9555, 0.9900, and 0.9997, respectively. The complete, star and line topologies are three representative communication topologies and have broad applications. In particular, the complete topology has the largest possible connectivity degree (densest) and is typical for, e.g., secure mulitparty computation tasks (Cramer et al., 2015); the star topology depicts the (sparse) spoke–hub distribution paradigm and is common in, e.g., cloud computing (Chao, 2015); and the line topology has the smallest possible connectivity degree (sparsest) for connected graphs and is widely used in, e.g., power systems (Gäde et al., 2017). The other three cases depict three different connectivity degrees in between and are used to simulate general sparse graphs covering a wider range of connectivity degrees. The trajectories of θ~i​l(1)​(k)superscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑖𝑙1𝑘\tilde{\theta}_{il}^{(1)}(k) for all i∈𝒱𝑖𝒱i\in\mathcal{V} under these six communication topologies are shown in Fig. 7. We can see that under all the six communication topologies, all the 100 trajectories converge to the value of the desired global sum 1.04, but clearly with descending convergence rates, which matches discussion above. By (27), we can see that the convergence rate can be estimated by the decaying rate of ‖N​(A(t))k−1N​1NT‖norm𝑁superscriptsuperscript𝐴𝑡𝑘subscript1𝑁superscriptsubscript1𝑁𝑇\|N(A^{(t)})^{k}-1_{N}1_{N}^{T}\|. The trajectories of ‖N​(A(1))k−1N​1NT‖norm𝑁superscriptsuperscript𝐴1𝑘subscript1𝑁superscriptsubscript1𝑁𝑇\|N(A^{(1)})^{k}-1_{N}1_{N}^{T}\| under the above six communication topologies are shown in Fig. 8 (the small figure shows the convergence under the line topology). It matches the convergence rates observed in Fig. 7. Notice that the trajectory of ∥N(Ak−1N1NT∥\|N(A^{k}-1_{N}1_{N}^{T}\| for a given matrix A𝐴A can be generated offline. Hence, if the learners have prior knowledge of average connectivity degree of 𝒢(t)superscript𝒢𝑡\mathcal{G}^{(t)}, then based on the decaying rate of ‖N​(A(t))k−1N​1NT‖norm𝑁superscriptsuperscript𝐴𝑡𝑘subscript1𝑁superscriptsubscript1𝑁𝑇\|N(A^{(t)})^{k}-1_{N}1_{N}^{T}\| for possible communication topologies, they may be able to choose a less conservative value of K𝐾K.

Finally we verify the computational efficiency of Algorithm 2. Intuitively, a learner’s computational overhead is mainly determined by the total number of shares it needs to generate and the number of iterations of the consensus process. We first examine the relationship between computational overhead and the total number of shares. This number depends on two factors, one is 𝒩¯i(t)superscriptsubscript¯𝒩𝑖𝑡\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{i}^{(t)}, the number of its neighbors including itself, and the other is n𝑛n, the dimension of θ(t)superscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{(t)}. Notice that the first factor is related to the size of learners. In each training round t𝑡t, a learner’s total number of shares is 𝒩¯i(t)​nsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒩𝑖𝑡𝑛\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{i}^{(t)}n. To examine the relationship between the computational overhead and 𝒩¯i(t)​nsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒩𝑖𝑡𝑛\bar{\mathcal{N}}_{i}^{(t)}n, an easy way is to tune the values of n𝑛n by tuning the values of hℎh, the number of hidden layers of the learners local autoencoders (recall that n=1569​h+784𝑛1569ℎ784n=1569h+784). Without loss of generality, the following simulations adopt a fixed communication topology, where the learners’ connectivity degrees are well balanced (i.e., they have similar number of neighbors). We use an arbitrary such communication topology where the average number of neighbors for one learner is 87. For each value of n𝑛n, Algorithm 2 is run for T=10𝑇10T=10 rounds, and in each round t𝑡t, the consensus algorithm is run for K=10𝐾10K=10 iterations. The results are shown in the left sub-figure of Fig. 9, where the x𝑥x-axis is the average number of total shares per learner per round (in this case, 87​n87𝑛87n), and the y𝑦y-axis is the average time per learner per training round for the phase of global model aggregation (steps 4–14 of Algorithm 2). From the left sub-figure of Fig. 9, we can see that when the average total number of shares per learner per round is 106superscript10610^{6}, the average time per learner per training round is merely around 2.4 seconds. In addition, this sub-figure illustrates that the average time per learner per training round grows linearly with the average total number of shares per learner per round, where the growth rate is very slow, approximately 2.315×10−62.315superscript1062.315\times 10^{-6}. This verifies that our algorithm is computationally efficient and scales well with large-size dense networks and high dimensional training models. Next we examine the relationship between the running time for the consensus process (step 10 of Algorithm 2) and the number of consensus iterations K𝐾K. The above communication topology is adopted and fixed. For each value of K𝐾K, Algorithm 2 is run for T=10𝑇10T=10 rounds, and in each round t𝑡t, the consensus algorithm is run for K𝐾K iterations. The results are shown in the right sub-figure of Fig. 9, where the x𝑥x-axis is the value of K𝐾K, and the y𝑦y-axis is the average consensus time per learner per training round. From the right sub-figure of Fig. 9, we can see that when K=105𝐾superscript105K=10^{5}, the average consensus time per learner per training round is merely around 0.6153 seconds. In addition, this sub-figure shows that the average consensus time per learner per training round grows linearly with the value of K𝐾K, where the growth rate is also very slow, approximately 6.155×10−66.155superscript1066.155\times 10^{-6}. This verifies that our algorithm is also computationally efficient for sparse networks which may need a large number of consensus iterations.

8. Conclusions and Future Works

This paper developed a new algorithm for privacy-preserving decentralized federated learning over a time-varying communication graph. A consensus-based framework is adopted to enable decentralized global model aggregation. In each round of model aggregation, the Metropolis-Hastings method is applied to update the weighted adjacency matrix based on the current communication topology so as to ensure convergence of average consensus. The technique of Shamir’s secret sharing scheme is further integrated with the consensus-based framework to facilitate privacy preservation. The correctness and privacy properties of the proposed algorithm are both analyzed. Its correctness, convergence rate and computational overhead are examined by a case study on a federated learning application using the MNIST dataset. Beyond global model aggregation in federated learning, the proposed algorithm can be readily applied to general secure aggregation tasks over sparse time-varying communication graphs, e.g., decentralized opinions agreement, multi-vehicle rendezvous, and energy supply/consumption aggregation. Moreover, it can also be applied to facilitate privacy for more complicated problems that are solvable by consensus-based approaches (Kia et al., 2019), e.g., distributed formation control, state estimation, unconstrained convex optimization, and resource allocation.

An interesting future work topic is to extend the attacker model to also include active attacks. For example, with external data poisoning attacks, data transmitted over communication links may be tampered by external attackers; and with Byzantine attacks, the learners themselves may be corrupted to maliciously deviate from the designed algorithm. In the presence of both passive and active attacks, a resilient algorithm needs to be developed which can preserve privacy and meanwhile maintain a satisfactory learning performance.
